question: How many 3D models are indexed in ShapeNet, and how many of these models are classified into specific categories?
answer: ShapeNet has indexed roughly 3,000,000 models. Out of these, 220,000 models are classified into 3,135 categories based on WordNet synsets.
reference: \"ShapeNet: An Information-Rich 3D Model Repository,\" Abstract: \"At the time of this technical report, ShapeNet has indexed more than 3,000,000 models, 220,000 models out of which are classified into 3,135 categories (WordNet synsets).\"

question: What portion of models in ShapeNetCore are from the airplane category, and how does this compare to the total number of models in ShapeNetCore?
answer: In ShapeNetCore, there are 4045 models in the airplane category out of a total of 57,386 models, which constitutes about 7% of the ShapeNetCore dataset.
reference: \"ShapeNet: An Information-Rich 3D Model Repository,\" Section 'ShapeNetCore': \"Total number of models for the top 100 ShapeNetSem categories ... 02691156 (airplane) 4045 ... Total 57386.\"

question: What is the size of the Objaverse 1.0 dataset in terms of the number of 3D models, and how many artists contributed to it?
answer: The Objaverse 1.0 dataset contains over 800,000 3D models and was contributed to by over 100,000 artists.
reference: Objaverse: A Universe of Annotated 3D Objects, Section: Introduction: \"In total, \\data contains over \\textbf{800K} 3D assets designed by over \\textbf{100K} artists which makes this data large and diversely sourced.\"

question: What improvement in Top-1 classification accuracy was observed when comparing the performance of the ViT-L/14 model on randomly rotated objects versus any rotations in the robustness analysis?
answer: The Top-1 classification accuracy of the ViT-L/14 model improved by 23.2%, from 29.1% on randomly rotated objects to 52.3% on any rotations.
reference: Objaverse: A Universe of Annotated 3D Objects, Section: Analyzing Robustness: \"ViT-L/14 & 29.1\\% & 54.5\\% & \\textbf{52.3\\%} & 77.2\\% & 23.2\\%.\"

question: What is the scale of the Objaverse-XL dataset, and how does it compare to previous datasets in terms of size?
answer: The Objaverse-XL dataset comprises over 10.2 million 3D objects, making it more than an order of magnitude larger than its predecessor, Objaverse 1.0, which had 800,000 objects. It is two orders of magnitude larger than ShapeNet, which has 51,000 3D models.
reference: \"Objaverse-XL introduces a dataset of over 10 million 3D objects...representing an order of magnitude more data than the recently proposed Objaverse 1.0 and is two orders of magnitude larger than ShapeNet.\" - Section on Objaverse-XL.

question: What improvements were noted when training the Zero123 model using the Objaverse-XL dataset compared to Objaverse 1.0?
answer: Training the Zero123 model using the Objaverse-XL dataset resulted in significantly better zero-shot generalization to challenging and complex modalities such as photorealistic assets, cartoons, drawings, and sketches. The synthesis quality consistently improved from a thousand assets up to 10 million, as demonstrated by experiments showing improvements in view synthesis quality and zero-shot generalization performance.
reference: \"The recently proposed Zero123 model for novel view synthesis, when pre-trained with Objaverse-XL, shows significantly better zero-shot generalization to challenging and complex modalities...\" - Section on Zero123-XL and \"Improvement with Scale.\"
